data.title: Chinese Regulator Greenlights Tasly Pharmaceutical Stake Transfer
data.description:
Tasly Pharmaceutical Group said the acquisition of its 28% stake by China Resources Sanjiu was approved by China's State Administration for Market Regulation.

China Resources Sanjiu recently received an official "no prohibition" decision from the regulator regarding its planned acquisition of a 28% stake in Tasly Pharma, according to a Wednesday filing with the Shanghai bourse.

Following the transaction, the pharmaceutical company's controlling shareholder will change to China Resources Sanjiu from Tasly Group.

data.title: Australia's BlueBet soars on acquisition of Topsport
data.description:
** Shares of online wagering provider and bookmaker BlueBet Holdings rise 9.1% to A$0.36

** Co says it will acquire Australian sports and racing betting company Topsport for A$15 mln ($9.36 mln)

** Says acquisition brings it closer to its target of 10% to 15% market share in Australia

** Stock earlier rose as much as 10.7%

** About 1.6 mln shares change hands, 5x the 30-day average

* Stock has risen 16.67% YTD, including session's moves

($1 = 1.6026 Australian dollars)

data.title: The additional US tariffs of 10% will apply to Hong Kong as well as mainland China
data.description:
The additional US tariffs of 10% will apply to Hong Kong as well as mainland China - US Customs and Border Protection notice says

**

data.title: BOJ official: BOJ sees underlying inflation gradually heading towards 2%
data.description:
Bank of Japan Policy Head Kazuhiro Masaki speaking in parliament

  • BOJ sees underlying inflation gradually heading toward 2%
  • Price rises post-pandemic have been driven mostly by cost-push factors, such as rising import costs from weak yen
  • Expect cost-push inflation pressure to gradually dissipate ahead
  • Services prices rising moderately

data.title: Underlying economic data, not forecasting errors blight investment decisions
data.description:
Economic data continues to make news in more ways than one. The base year for GDP is being moved from 2011-12 to 2022-23 with improvements in estimations being targeted, including aligning them with the WPI, CPI and the IIP, a frequent source of discord in the past. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is also being revised and base year moved from 2012 to 2024.

The new RBI governor is reportedly reviewing RBI’s internal forecasting tools for inflation and growth so as to minimise projection errors. These include adding a wide spectrum of data sets and the use of machine learning to pre-empt price fluctuations in volatile items such as food. Having taken flak for getting estimates wrong many times, this is understandable.

Underlying data is the real problem

But the larger problem is with actual economic data itself being flaky, not so much forecasting. World Economics, a data analytics firm, has a "C" rating assigned to India which means its GDP data should be used with caution.

Questions arising from change in GDP base year

The issues with GDP data are old and well known. Some of them were addressed during the previous base year change in 2011-12. An important change then made was the move from volume to value, with the method of calculating value added itself drastically changed. This became controversial as some indicators improved dramatically. In manufacturing, the change from IIP/ASI data to corporate balance sheets led to value-add growing faster than actual output.

Real GDP as a whole grew at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 5.7 percent from fiscal 2011-12 to 2022-23, while IIP went up by only 3 percent per annum, raising questions of credibility. In services too, using indirect taxes to measure changes in value resulted in higher growth rates that seemed inexplicable. But old shortcomings persisted.

The IIP, still in use as a high frequency volume series, had less than 20 percent value-based items even though GDP was itself a value-added measure. The IIP also failed to adequately capture the unregistered sector. Further, it did not take into account improvements in capacity or technological changes and its fixed weights (as of 2011-12) meant that it missed newer products such as smartphones.

The other crucial data peg is the Annual Survey of Industries (ASI) which has also been problematic. Annual GDP estimates use ASI data instead of IIP, which are used for quarterly estimates. The ASI is a product of the 1960s industrial period and covered only units set up under the Factories Act, which left out a large number of industries outside the Act.

Data for unregistered manufacturing (non-ASI) was collected only once in five years on a sample basis and the IIP was used for extrapolating the benchmark estimates. Also, ASI data came delayed with a lag of 2-3 years which meant that GDP data also got constantly revised.

The famed double-deflator versus the single-deflator issue (which is currently used to deflate nominal data) is another known problem, but this has tended to be downplayed as being an acceptable feature and not a bug.

For at least two important segments of the economy, namely the informal sector and services, primary data availability has been poor, necessitating derivations based on productivity estimations and labour force data. For instance, in many of the service sectors, gross value added (GVA) is derived as the product of estimated labour force and value add per worker, the latter obtained from surveys, some done only once in five years. For the years other than the survey year, estimates were simply extrapolated using appropriate price and quantity (IIP) indices.

With the informal sector more than 70 percent of the economy and services contributing over half of total GDP, a significant chunk of GDP could be said to be “derived” actuals based on estimations from surveys. Clearly firmer data is required for the services and perhaps an Annual Survey of Services, on the lines of the ASI could help.

CPI’s issues are conceptual, not data-related

As regards measuring inflation, the CPI is a critical tool for both monetary policy and for deflating nominal GDP to real terms. But the considerations here are about conceptual issues, such as the treatment of free goods and services, rather than data. The Government seems to be clear about the intended usage of CPI when it says that being a measurement of inflation and an input into monetary policy, the scope of the index should be restricted to monetary transactions only. Here it is worth understanding how inflation tracking works in other economies.

The US tracks retail inflation through two measures viz. the personal consumption Expenditure (PCE) index and the CPI. The PCE reflects changes in the complete prices of goods and services purchased by consumer, not just the out-of-pocket expenses, while the CPI deals with only actual out-of-pocket spends by consumers. In items such as healthcare, this difference can be significant with actual health care costs incurred by the consumer and the economy being different.In essence, the CPI is based on a survey of what households are buying and the PCE on what businesses are selling. This also reflects in the different weights in the two indices. The important difference is in their purpose, one for macro policy, the other about living standards. The US Fed prefers the PCE to gauge inflation at a macro level as it reflects substitution effects better when prices change, while the CPI reflects changes in actual living standards of consumers. The recent debates in India over including food prices in CPI inflation when making monetary policy decisions, comes to mind. Perhaps having two indices could help, though some have argued that the WPI is in some sense similar to the PCE.

data.title: OzAurum Resources Discovers Visible Gold at Western Australia Project; Shares Hit One-Year High
data.description:
OzAurum Resources found visible gold from a recently drilled air-core intersection at the Mulgabbie North project in Western Australia, according to a Wednesday filing with the Australian bourse.

The discovery returned assay results of 4 meters at 14.17 grams per tonne grade of gold from 16 meters, with up to 50% quartz observed in multiple high-grade intervals, the filing said.

A reverse circulation drilling rig is expected to arrive late next week to further explore the discovery, according to the filing.

Shares rose more than 49% in afternoon trade Wednesday and reached their highest in 52 weeks.

data.title: China Lodges WTO Complaint Against US After Launching Retaliatory Tariffs
data.description:
China filed a complaint against the US over its imposition of a 10% tariff on Chinese products, the Ministry of Commerce said Tuesday.

The complaint came the same day China imposed tariffs of 10% to 15% on some US products, such as coal and liquified natural gas or LNG, and imposed sanctions on Calvin Klein maker PVH and biotech firm Illumina in what is widely seen as retaliatory measures against the US.

China also launched a probe into Google over alleged antitrust violations.

These developments came after US President Donald Trump imposed 10% duties on Chinese imports, which took effect on Tuesday.

data.title: Australia government sells A$15 billion of new 2036 bonds
data.description:
The Australian government's debt management arm said on Wednesday it had sold A$15 billion ($9.38 billion) of new 2036 bonds through a syndicated offer.

The Australian Office of Financial Management (AOFM) said the offer of 4.25% March 21, 2036 Treasury bonds drew bids worth A$83.4 billion, which would be a record for such a sale. The bonds priced at a yield to maturity of 4.46%.

Joint-lead managers of the issue were Barrenjoey Markets Pty Ltd, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, National Australia Bank Limited and UBS AG, Australia Branch.

($1 = 1.5992 Australian dollars)

data.title: Yokogawa Electric's Nine-Month Profit Falls 26%; Shares Down 6%
data.description:
Yokogawa Electric reported a 25.7% year-on-year decline in profits, reaching 38.7 billion yen in the fiscal nine months ended Dec. 31, 2024, from 52.1 billion yen a year earlier due to the absence of the previous year's extraordinary income from selling investment securities.

Basic earnings per share fell to 148.74 yen from 197.81 yen a year ago, according to a Tokyo Stock Exchange filing on Tuesday.

Net sales increased 4.0% to 408.9 billion yen from 393.1 billion yen a year earlier.

The company projected attributable profit to fall 17.3% to 51 billion yen, with net sales expected to increase 4.2% to 563 billion yen.

Yokogawa Electric expects to pay a final dividend of 29 yen per share for the fiscal year ending March 31.

Shares of Yokogawa Electric lost nearly 6% recently.

data.title: India's Sensex Opens 0.2% Higher at 78704.60, Led by Tech Stocks
Hong Kong Sees Marginal Improvements in Private Sector But Expectations Remain Downbeat, S&P Says
data.description:
Hong Kong's private sector recorded continued but marginal improvement in its business conditions in January, despite business expectations staying downbeat, according to a Wednesday press release by S&P.

The S&P Global Hong Kong SAR Purchasing Manager's Index slipped to 51.0 in January from 51.1 in December 2024, staying in expansionary territory but at the lowest since September 2024.

New orders grew but at the softest pace since the 18-month peak last seen in October due to weak consumer spending and a slump in business, according to S&P.

New business from mainland China fell the greatest since April 2022 while exports slipped for the third month, the debt watcher said.

Employment in Hong Kong's private sector increased the second time in the past nine months due to higher recruitment in the services and wholesale/retail sectors, S&P said.

Purchasing activity expansion was the slowest during the month, while supplier performance fell for the sixth straight month due to shipping delays and insufficient spare capacity, and input price inflation was the highest in three months.

Business expectations also stayed downbeat, but confidence continues to rise from the 13-month low seen in November, S&P said.

data.title: New Zealand Dollar Extends Gains
data.description:
The New Zealand dollar rose to around $0.566 on Wednesday, extending gains from the previous session, as the US dollar weakened amid tariff tensions.

A 10% US tariff on Chinese goods took effect on Tuesday, prompting Beijing to announce retaliatory tariffs on selected US products.

While a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping remains uncertain, such discussions are seen as pivotal for potentially easing or delaying tariffs, like how last-minute talks resulted in one-month reprieves on levies against Canada and Mexico.

Domestically, the Kiwi shrugged off weak labor market data, which reinforced expectations of a 50bps rate cut by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand later this month.

The country’s unemployment rate rose to 5.1% in Q4, the highest since Q3 2020, underscoring the extent of the economic slowdown.

Additionally, weaker-than-expected services activity data from China, New Zealand’s largest trading partner, weighed on the currency.

data.title: Hillgrove Resources Increases Production From South Australia Copper-Gold Mine; Shares Rise 8%
data.description:
Hillgrove Resources increased copper production in January from the Kanmantoo copper-gold mine in South Australia, according to an Australian bourse filing on Wednesday.

The company reported copper production of 903 tonnes in January, compared with a monthly average production of 879 tonnes in the December 2024 quarter.

It processed 99,000 tonnes of ore in the month, compared with a monthly average of 110,000 tonnes in the December 2024 quarter. However, it mined 115,000 tonnes of ore in January, compared with 104,000 tonnes on average each month in the December 2024 quarter.

The firm's shares rose almost 8% in recent trading on Wednesday.

data.title: Shares of China tungsten producers rally on Beijing's latest export curbs
data.description:
Shares of major Chinese tungsten producers rallied on Wednesday as markets reacted to Beijing's latest critical mineral export controls on the first day of trading after the week-long Lunar New Year holiday.

Soon after fresh U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods took effect on Tuesday, China said it would restrict exports of five critical minerals — tungsten, indium, bismuth, tellurium, and molybdenum — used in defence, clean energy and other industries to "safeguard national security interests."

Xiamen Tungsten , China Tungsten and High-tech Materials and Chongyi Zhangyuan Tungsten climbed over 3%,while CMOC jumped by over 1% as of 0206 GMT.

In past cases where China has imposed export curbs on other critical minerals, as in August 2023, prices jumped to the signal the metals newfound importance. Some Chinese exporters will also be able to take advantage of the expected rally in prices overseas once they secure export licenses.

Tungsten is an ultra-hard metal, in terms of strength outdone only by diamonds, and is primarily used in the production of goods including artillery shells, armour plating and cutting tools.

China produced over 80% of global tungsten supply in 2023, according to data from the United States Geological Survey (USGS).

While tungsten resources exist outside China, analysts and traders say certain specialised tungsten products used by the aerospace and defence industries have few non-Chinese alternatives.

"The export controls on APT and tungsten carbide could be the worst affected as there are few alternatives for tungsten in aerospace and defence applications," said Sian Morris, non-ferrous metals analyst at information provider Argus. APT is a compound used in production of various tungsten products.

"Russia was previously a major supplier of tungsten products, but China has grown its share of the global tungsten market since the start of Russia's war in Ukraine."

data.title: Inari Amertron Likely to Face Earnings Pressure — Market Talk
data.description: Inari Amertron's FY 2025-FY 2026 earnings my be pressured by weaker radio frequency revenue as handset sales slow down, CGS International analysts Shafiq Kadir and Dharmini Thuraisingam say in a note. Margin dilution from new packaging ventures could add pressure on earnings, they write, as CGS cuts its forecast for Inari's FY 2025-FY 2026 EPS by 19%-20%. However, margins may recover by FY 2026-FY 2027 with new businesses scaling up production, they add. CGS International lowers Inari's target price to MYR2.60 from MYR2.90, while maintaining a hold rating, citing near-term risks from a subdued automotive market and policy uncertainties under the Trump administration. Shares are 0.4% lower at MYR2.44. (yingxian.wong@wsj.com)

data.title: RBNZ on Track to Cut Rate by 50 Basis Points in February in Wake of Q4 2024 Labor Data, Says ANZ Research
data.description:
New Zealand's latest unemployment data cement the projected 50-basis-point cut at the Reserve Bank's (RBNZ) upcoming meeting on Feb. 19, as the labor market heads towards stabilization in the first half, ANZ Research said in a Wednesday note.

The unemployment rate rose to 5.1% in the fourth quarter of 2024, in line with expectations, from 4.8% in the prior three-month period.

"The underlying details of the release highlight that the labor market is operating with a large degree of excess capacity, and measures of wage growth remain on a path to levels consistent with inflation near the RBNZ's 2% target midpoint," ANZ Research wrote.

Analysts at ANZ Research continue to expect a 25-basis-point cut in April.

data.title: Philippines Higher-Than-Expected January Inflation Supports Rate Cut — Market Talk
data.description: The Philippines' higher-than-expected January inflation print has cleared the way for a rate cut from the BSP next week, Barclays economist Shreya Sodhani says in a note. Although headline CPI rose 2.9% on year, it remained at the midpoint of BSP's 2.5%-3.3% forecast range, she writes. Inflation was driven by food prices, which usually rise in January, she says. The latest inflation print and slower-than-expected 4Q GDP growth suggest that a rate cut is the most likely outcome, she adds. However, there are risks that the BSP could delay rate cuts, as officials have suggested that the central bank may ease only once in 1H and another time in 2H, she says. Barclays continues to expect three rate cuts this year. (amanda.lee@wsj.com)

data.title: Vietnam govt says January CPI up 3.63% y/y
data.description:
Vietnam's consumer price index rose 3.63% in January from a year earlier while industrial production rose a modest 0.6% due to the Lunar New Year holidays late in the month, the government said on Wednesday.

The figures were published on the government's portal one day before the statistics office was due to release January data for a range of macroeconomic indicators.

Retails sales rose 9.5% in January from a year earlier, the government said in a statement.

It said the trade surplus for January came in at $1.23 billion.

The government said foreign investment inflows rose 2% in January from a year earlier to more than $1.5 billion, and foreign investment pledges rose an annual 48.6% to $4.3 billion.

"The banking system operated safely and stably", it said.

data.title: Global Forex and Fixed Income Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering FX and Fixed Income. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires throughout the day.

0339 GMT - The Bank of Korea may cut its policy rate later this month despite January's pickup in domestic inflation, Barclays economist Bum Ki Son writes in a note. Headline inflation accelerated to 2.2% from 1.9% in December, but the BOK may focus on soft core inflation and weak domestic demand, Son says. Core inflation, which strips out volatile food and energy prices, ticked up to 1.9% from 1.8% in December. BOK policymakers see forex-related pressures as limited and oil prices as a one-off shock, he notes. "As such, we believe inflation is unlikely to stop the BOK from cutting rates 25bp at its February meeting," he says. (kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com)

0338 GMT - The Philippines' higher-than-expected January inflation print has cleared the way for a rate cut from the BSP next week, Barclays economist Shreya Sodhani says in a note. Although headline CPI rose 2.9% on year, it remained at the midpoint of BSP's 2.5%-3.3% forecast range, she writes. Inflation was driven by food prices, which usually rise in January, she says. The latest inflation print and slower-than-expected 4Q GDP growth suggest that a rate cut is the most likely outcome, she adds. However, there are risks that the BSP could delay rate cuts, as officials have suggested that the central bank may ease only once in 1H and another time in 2H, she says. Barclays continues to expect three rate cuts this year. (amanda.lee@wsj.com)

0323 GMT - China's target measures unveiled on Tuesday leave room for potential talks with the U.S., say two economists at BofA Global Research in a research report. "These announcements mark a measured and comprehensive retaliation that seeks to target U.S. business interests, while minimizing the impact on China's economy," the economists say. China seems to be carefully targeting energy products which the country has the potential to purchase more of, they say. "In potential negotiations in the future, reaching a deal where China pledges to buy more oil and gas from the U.S. may be more desirable than China reducing such imports on higher tariffs," the economists add. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

0314 GMT - The U.S. Treasury 10-year yield still faces downside risk, based on daily charts, says Quek Ser Leang of UOB's Global Economics & Markets Research in a research report. There's a possibility the 10-year yield will fall into the daily Ichimoku cloud, which is currently between 4.318% and 4.447%, the markets strategist says. Going forward, a break of the 10-year yield below the bottom of the daily Ichimoku cloud might potentially trigger sharp declines, the strategist says. On the other hand, if the 10-year yield rises above 4.690%, this would suggest that the 10-year yield is likely to trade in a range, the strategist adds. Treasury 10-year yield is steady at 4.5167%. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

0257 GMT - Stronger-than-expected labor cash earnings growth in Japan and an expansionary services PMI reading continues to support BOJ policy normalization, ING's Min Joo Kang says. Data released earlier showed solid on-year labor cash earnings growth in December, with base earnings rising steadily for a second month, while January's services PMI marked its highest level since September 2024. "Strong wage growth is likely to lead to consumption growth and keep inflation above 2%," the economist says. The market is pricing in another BOJ rate hike in July, but ING forecasts a move in May is possible, especially if this year's Shunto wage talk results are as strong as last year's. ING now sees BOJ's terminal rate at 1.25% versus 1.0% previously, tipping hikes in May and October of 2025, followed by another in 2026. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

0254 GMT - The future path of the U.S.-China trade conflict remains highly uncertain, say Goldman Sachs analysts in a note. China's retaliatory tariffs appear much less than proportional compared to the U.S.'s 10% across-the-board additional tariff on $525 billion worth of Chinese goods, they write. However, the combination of retaliatory tariffs with export bans, entity list additions, and antitrust probe into Google, suggests a "more coordinated and comprehensive approach by [Chinese] policymakers" than during the 2018-2019 U.S.-China trade war, they say. In the coming days, the U.S.'s reactions to China's retaliation will be among key events to watch, they add. (amanda.lee@wsj.com)

0230 GMT - Unemployment in New Zealand is still rising despite rapid interest-rate cuts since mid-2024, leaving consumers and business owners still searching to see the light of an economic recovery. Mark Smith, senior economist at ASB Bank expects demand for labor will continue to weaken until a modest economic recovery finally shows up in the second half of 2025. Firms will have to carefully manage employee headcount in that time, he adds. With inflation close to the target midpoint and monetary settings still slowing the economy, further swift monetary easing looks appropriate to limit economic and labor market scarring, he adds. (james.glynn@wsj.com; @JamesGlynnWSJ)

0225 GMT - Japan's services sector is off to a strong start in 2025, the au Jibun Bank PMI compiled by S&P Global suggests. January data point to a solid upturn in business activity across the sector, accompanied by a steeper, solid rise in new business inflows. The survey signaled a sharp jump in average prices charged by service providers, while exports rose for the first time in four months. Firms are upbeat on their prospects over the coming 12 months and have boosted staffing levels, says Usamah Bhatti, economist at S&P Global Market Intelligence. Services continue to underpin growth in Japan's private sector, contrasting the weakness in manufacturing. Still, companies are confident that private-sector activity will rise over 2025, expecting a rebound in manufacturing output and a broad-based economic recovery, Bhatti says. (fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com)

0226 GMT - The yen strengthens against other G-10 and Asian currencies in the morning session. Japanese data released earlier showed the economy's real wages rose 0.6% in December from a year earlier, marking a second straight month of increases. A solid rise in Japanese labor cash earnings will reinforce the current market pricing in at least one more rate hike by the BOJ this year, CBA's Joseph Capurso says in a note. In addition, with the 'tariff war' between the U.S. and other countries seemingly ongoing, the AUD/JPY is likely to retest support at 94.69, the head of International and Sustainable Economics adds. USD/JPY falls 0.6% to 153.36; AUD/JPY drops 0.7% to 95.88. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

0213 GMT - There are reasons to be hopeful that a recovery in New Zealand's economy in the second half of this year will help businesses avoid more cuts to headcount, says Mary Jo Vergara, an economist at Kiwibank. But should the required rate relief not come from the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, the risk of further ​job losses only grows, she says. The RBNZ's current forecasts suggest the OCR will get to 3.5% this year and no lower until deep in 2027. That will leave monetary conditions too restrictive, Vergara says. RBNZ will need to get the OCR down to 3% this year. Holding out longer will only cause unnecessary and indeed avoidable damage to the labor market, she adds. (james.glynn@wsj.com; @JamesGlynnWSJ)

0144 GMT - There are no signs yet that aggressive interest rate cuts by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand since mid-2024 are gaining traction and lifting the economy, says Ben Jarman, chief economist at JP Morgan. To be sure, recent GDP revisions show a more worrying economic trajectory, he adds. The data have yet to turn up meaningfully because policy traction is still being blunted by earlier OCR hikes, he adds. This has slowed the lowering of new mortgage rates, and any improvement in disposable incomes, Jarman says. A number of households will still be rolling their mortgages into higher rates than previous, he adds. (james.glynn@wsj.com; @JamesGlynnWSJ)

0146 GMT - JGBs fall in price terms during the morning Tokyo session. Data released earlier show Japan's real wages rose 0.6% in December from a year earlier, marking a second straight month of increases and adding to the case for another BOJ rate hike. The sharp rise in the BOJ's core CPI inflation forecasts in the January outlook report, together with Gov. Ueda's recent comment that there's "still a significant distance to the neutral rate of interest," has sparked worries over an acceleration of rate hikes and an increase in the terminal rate for this cycle, Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities' fixed income strategists say in a recent report. The JGB 10-year yield is 1.5 bps higher at 1.290%. (ronnie.harui@wsj.com)

data.title: Bank of Korea May Cut Rate This Month Despite Inflation Pickup — Market Talk
data.description: The Bank of Korea may cut its policy rate later this month despite January's pickup in domestic inflation, Barclays economist Bum Ki Son writes in a note. Headline inflation accelerated to 2.2% from 1.9% in December, but the BOK may focus on soft core inflation and weak domestic demand, Son says. Core inflation, which strips out volatile food and energy prices, ticked up to 1.9% from 1.8% in December. BOK policymakers see forex-related pressures as limited and oil prices as a one-off shock, he notes. "As such, we believe inflation is unlikely to stop the BOK from cutting rates 25bp at its February meeting," he says. (kwanwoo.jun@wsj.com)

data.title: Macro Metals Unit Forms Indigenous Joint Venture With Robe River Kuruma Aboriginal Corporation; Shares Up 7%
data.description:
Macro Metals unit Macro Mining Services has formed an Indigenous joint venture with Robe River Kuruma Aboriginal Corporation's unit, Robe River Services, the company said in an Australian bourse filing on Wednesday.

Robe River Services holds 51% of the issued share capital of the joint venture named Robe River Kuruma Macro Mining and Macro Mining Services the other 49%, the filing said.

The joint venture will enjoy 'preferred' status in the award of works on mining projects as a local Indigenous contracting business, particularly on Robe River Kuruma Country, the filing added.

Macro Metals shares were up 7% in recent trade.

data.title: China PMI Gauge Signals Softer Services Sector Growth — Update
data.description:
A private gauge of China's service activity expanded at a slower clip in January, pointing in the same direction as official data as both demand and supply cooled at the start of the year.

The Caixin services purchasing managers index fell to 51.0 in January from 52.2 in December, said Caixin Media Co. and S&P Global on Wednesday.

Despite the slowdown, the measure remained above the 50 mark that separates activity contraction from expansion, and where it has been since January 2023.

New business growth eased to a four-month low in January, but export orders returned to growth after falling at the end of 2024, Caixin said.

The sustainability of strong external demand is uncertain amid rising trade tensions between Beijing and Washington. On Tuesday, China announced a series of retaliatory measures in response to President Trump's 10% tariff hike on all Chinese exports to the U.S.

Concerns about how trade uncertainty could hurt demand for services from China was reflected in the Caixin survey data.

While firms expressed hope that business growth plans and government policy can support sales in the next 12 months, confidence levels remained below average amid worries over rising competition and trade risks.

"Rising uncertainty on the international stage could worsen China's export environment, posing significant challenges for its economy," said Wang Zhe, senior economist at Caixin Insight Group.

With the economy also dealing with weak demand and sluggish consumer spending, "macroeconomic policies must be well-prepared and adjusted promptly to adapt to evolving circumstances," Wang said.

The Caixin services PMI subindex of employment tumbled to its lowest since April 2024, falling for a second consecutive month as companies continued to cut headcount and increase efficiency.

The lower headline Caixin reading was in line with the official gauge, which dropped to 50.3 in January from 52.0 in December as business operations were disrupted by the Lunar New Year holiday.

Softer services activity countered quicker manufacturing output growth to push the Caixin composite index down in January, with the pace of expansion decelerating to the lowest in four months and employment recording the fastest fall in 26 months.

"The Caixin services and composite PMIs released today add to growing evidence that China's economy lost momentum last month," said Zichun Huang, an economist at Capital Economics.

Focus now turns to travel and spending data for the just-concluded Lunar New Year holiday, which will shed light into consumer appetite in China. The figures, potentially due Wednesday, come as the government recently expanded trade-in programs to encourage more spending on home appliances, electronic devices and cars this year.

According to the latest numbers from the China Film Administration, box office revenue reached 9.51 billion yuan, or about $1.32 billion, during the holiday as more than 187 million moviegoers went to the cinemas, both at historic highs.

Write to Singapore editors at singaporeeditors@dowjones.com

data.title: LG Electronics to Showcase New Products at ISE 2025 in Barcelona
data.description:
LG Electronics will showcase digital signage products at the Integrated Systems Europe (ISE) 2025 in Barcelona this week.

The products include an AI-powered kinetic LED display, upgraded LG MAGNIT micro LEDs, and high-brightness outdoor signage featuring anti-discoloration technology, LG Electronics said Tuesday.

The exhibition will also present LG's advanced retail kiosks, fire-safe digital signages, and the LG CreateBoard lineup for education and corporate sectors, along with the LG Business Cloud platform for display management.

Shares of LG Electronics rose more than 2% in recent trade on Wednesday.

data.title: Marubeni CEO: Will Continue To Increase Our Offshore Wind Assets Prudently
data.description:
Marubeni Corp :

  • MARUBENI CEO: ADVISED OFFSHORE WIND POWER TEAM TO DEVELOP CALMLY AND AVOID EXCESSIVE COMPETITION

  • MARUBENI CEO: TRUMP ADMINISTRATION'S POLICIES WILL LIKELY ENABLE US TO CAPITALIZE ON GROWTH POTENTIAL OF OUR BUSINESSES TARGETING U.S. DOMESTIC DEMAND

  • MARUBENI CEO: WE ARE VERY INTERESTED IN THE U.S. SHALE GAS AND OTHER RESOURCE BUSINESSES

  • MARUBENI CEO: ENTERING ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT FROM SCRATCH IS CHALLENGING DUE TO HIGH RISKS INVOLVED

  • MARUBENI CEO: WILL CONTINUE TO INCREASE OUR OFFSHORE WIND ASSETS PRUDENTLY

data.title: Gold rises to all-time high on Sino-US tariff war
data.description:
Key points:
  • Gold hits all-time high at $2,853.97
  • Next major inflection point is probably $3,000 - analyst
  • Trump says he is no hurry to speak to Chinese President

Gold prices hit a record high on Wednesday, bolstered by fears of a new trade war between the United States and China after Beijing slapped tariffs on U.S. imports in a response to new U.S. duties on Chinese goods.

Spot gold was up 0.2% at $2,848.69 per ounce, as of 0253 GMT, after hitting a record high of $2,853.97 earlier in the session. U.S. gold futures gained 0.2% to $2,879.70.

U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he is in no hurry to speak to Chinese President Xi Jinping to try to defuse the trade tensions between the world's two largest economies.

China imposed targeted tariffs on U.S. imports on Tuesday and put several companies, including Google, on notice for possible sanctions, in a measured response to Trump's tariffs.

"The next major inflection point for gold is probably the $3,000 figure... China may be more encouraged to keep buying gold for reserves if the trade war escalates," said Ilya Spivak, head of global macro at Tastylive.

Meanwhile, the Trump administration's plans for trade tariffs come with inflation risks, three Federal Reserve officials warned on Monday, with one arguing that uncertainty over the price outlook calls for slower interest rate cuts than otherwise.

While gold is considered an inflation hedge, higher interest rates could dampen its appeal among investors.

Key economic data on investors' radar this week includes the ADP employment report due at 1315 GMT and the payrolls report on Friday, which could shed more light on the health of the U.S. economy.

"Gold demand ought to be partially supportive for other precious metals but their sensitivity to risk appetite has seen them underperform," said Spivak.

Spot silver rose 0.2% to $32.15 per ounce, platinum edged 0.3% higher to $966.95, and palladium fell 0.9% to $981.75.

data.title: Nissan to Reject Honda's Merger Terms, Putting Deal in Peril — WSJ
data.description:
By Sean McLain and Megumi Fujikawa

Nissan's board is planning to reject Honda's terms for a combination of the two automakers, putting in danger a merger plan announced less than two months ago, people familiar with the matter said Wednesday.

Nissan's board was scheduled to meet later Wednesday, and the people cautioned that no final decision to kill the deal has been made.

The two Japanese automakers said on Dec. 23 that they planned to combine under a structure in which Honda and Nissan would both be subsidiaries of a single holding company.

In recent days, Honda presented a new proposal that would have made Nissan a subsidiary of Honda instead of the more equal structure originally planned, according to a person familiar with the negotiations. The person said Nissan found the new proposal unacceptable and planned to reject it.

The person said Nissan and Honda would continue other cooperation that predates the merger talks, including collaboration on software and electric vehicles.

If the plan to combine with Honda falls apart, it would raise pressure on Nissan to reassure lenders, employees and customers that it can survive amid stiff competition in the U.S. and China. Nissan has lost ground in both markets.

Nissan said in November that it would lay off 9,000 workers and slash its factory capacity by one-fifth to cut costs.

Write to Sean McLain at sean.mclain@wsj.com and Megumi Fujikawa at megumi.fujikawa@wsj.com

data.title: Nissan Plans to Reject Honda's Terms for Combination, Sources Say — WSJ
Nissan Board to Meet Wednesday to Discuss Honda Merger Plan, Sources Say — WSJ
Iron ore falters on Sino-US tariff war concerns, sluggish China growth
data.description:
Iron ore futures declined on Wednesday amid worries of heightened trade tensions between the U.S. and top consumer China, while slowing Chinese growth dampened market sentiment.

The most-traded May iron ore contract on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange (DCE) eased 0.62% to 804 yuan ($110.37) a metric ton as of 0316 GMT.

The benchmark March iron ore (SZZFH5) on the Singapore Exchange declined 0.85% to $104.15 a ton.

"Sentiment is likely to suffer as Chinese markets reopen and react to the barrage of tariffs on commodities," ANZ analysts said.

U.S. President Donald Trump's additional 10% tariff on all Chinese imports kicked in on Tuesday.

China responded with tariffs on U.S. imports in a rapid response to the new U.S. duties, renewing a trade war between the world's top two economies.

"Steelmaking raw materials will also be in focus... Chinese iron ore markets are likely to come under pressure amid concerns of weaker export driven demand," ANZ added.

Beijing's new measures include a 15% levy on U.S. coal, a key steelmaking ingredient.

Meanwhile, China's services activity expanded at a slower pace in January, though business sentiment improved, a private sector business survey showed.

The country's factory activity growth similarly slowed, a separate survey showed.

On the supply side, Rio Tinto , said on Tuesday it had begun clearing iron ore ships from two Western Australian ports as two tropical cyclones offshore complicate its efforts to repair infrastructure damaged by a cyclone last month.

In January, Rio warned that its first-quarter shipments could be affected by disruptions to rail operations following record rainfall.

Other steelmaking ingredients on the DCE lost ground, with coking coal NYMEX:ACT1! and coke (DCJcv1) losing 2.42% and 3.35%, respectively.

Most steel benchmarks on the Shanghai Futures Exchange fell. Rebar slid 1.36%, hot-rolled coil declined 1.7%, wire rod (SWRcv1) dipped 0.84%, while stainless steel gained nearly 1%.

($1 = 7.2844 Chinese yuan)
